title: 104_hr4077
content: The Act may be cited as the "Migratory Bird Treaty Reform Act of 1996". The Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918 implemented agreements with various countries to protect migratory birds. The Secretary of the Interior can regulate hunting of migratory birds to prevent overharvesting, with prohibitions on certain hunting methods in place for over 60 years. The hunting community has broadly accepted regulations on hunting migratory birds for over 60 years, except for issues related to baiting. Interpretive difficulties with baiting regulations have led to confusion, inconsistent enforcement, and citations for hunters trying to comply with the rules. Congressional hearings and a law enforcement advisory commission have addressed these challenges. Restrictions on hunting migratory birds with baiting must be clarified to protect the bird resource while ensuring fair chase principles and habitat management benefits. SEC. 3. CLARIFYING HUNTING PROHIBITIONS. Section 3 of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act is amended to prohibit the taking of migratory game birds with specific weapons and methods, including traps, snares, nets, certain firearms, and certain devices for concealment. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits the use of motor vehicles, motorboats, or sailboats to hunt migratory game birds, except for retrieving dead or crippled birds. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits hunting migratory birds using motor-driven conveyances, live birds as decoys, and recorded or electrically amplified bird calls. Additionally, it prohibits the use of certain types of shot for hunting waterfowl and restricts hunting over baited areas. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits hunting migratory birds over certain agricultural areas, including standing crops, flooded croplands, and moist soil on emergent marsh plants. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits hunting migratory birds over moist soil on emergent marsh plants that have been manipulated as part of normal wetland habitat practices. This includes species like watergrass, smartweed, bulrush, swamp timothy, spike rush, wild rice, and sedge. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits hunting migratory birds over areas baited with corn, wheat, or other grains to attract birds. Section 6 of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act is amended to deposit fines into a conservation fund for acquiring bird refuges. SEC. 5. PENALTIES. Amendment to Section 6(c) of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act allows the owner of personal property to post bond instead of seizing property during legal proceedings.
